executive_summary.weekly_overview: Over the past week, **sovereign debt developments spanned Africa, Asia, Latin America and advanced economies**. Notably, **Sri Lanka made strides in finalising its external debt overhaul** with bilateral agreements that push payments far into the future, while **Ghana recommenced servicing restructured Eurobond coupons** and resumed domestic debt auctions, signalling regained stability:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}. **Zambia’s IMF-supported programme remained on track**, securing a fresh disbursement and eyeing extension to consolidate debt sustainability gains:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}. In contrast, **activist pressure mounted for systemic fixes**, as delays in cases like Ethiopia’s creditor talks and South Sudan’s litigation underscored the limitations of current frameworks:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}. Meanwhile, **credit rating actions highlighted divergent fiscal trajectories**: Kenya and Oman received upgrades for improving liquidity and debt metrics:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}, whereas Fitch’s downgrade of China reflected mounting debt risks:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}. **Climate-linked instruments** continued to gain attention, though Grenada’s hurricane clause remained untriggered. Looking ahead, observers will monitor **election outcomes (e.g. Bolivia) and policy shifts** that could determine whether countries secure relief or face rising default risks. Overall, the week’s themes included the **push for inclusive debt restructurings, the impact of reforms on creditworthiness, and the persistent calls for innovation in sovereign debt governance**.
executive_summary.trend_analysis: Emerging markets with credible reform programs **saw rating improvements and market rallies**, whereas those lacking creditor coordination faced **protracted impasses**. The week illustrated a **two-track trend**: countries like Ghana, Kenya and Oman are restoring stability through restructurings or fiscal discipline, while others like Ethiopia and South Sudan continue to grapple with holdout creditors and legal challenges. There is a growing **momentum for new debt mechanisms** as civil society voices highlight systemic shortfalls. Overall, a pattern of **rewarding reformist momentum versus penalising inertia** is evident in sovereign risk pricing and ratings.

items.headline: Sri Lanka finalises bilateral debt deals, edges closer to completing restructuring

content.summary: **Sri Lanka’s external debt overhaul entered a decisive phase** as Colombo sealed a **bilateral restructuring agreement with the UK** worth nearly $90 million:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}. The deal, formalised on 22 August, reschedules payments on Sri Lanka’s post-default obligations to Britain out to 2042. This marks a “significant milestone” toward **completing Sri Lanka’s comprehensive debt restructuring**, which is now over 90% finished by value:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}. Sri Lanka has reached **terms with 98% of its external creditors**, including Paris Club members and China, delaying most debt service to beyond 2039. With these agreements in hand – a prerequisite for continued IMF support – the country is **on track to restore debt sustainability**, pending final arrangements with a few remaining commercial lenders. Next steps include concluding talks with holdout bondholders and **securing IMF Executive Board sign-off** on Sri Lanka’s progress.
next_milestones: Finish negotiations with residual private creditors
IMF program review in Q4 2025

items.headline: Ghana resumes domestic debt servicing, boosting market confidence post-restructuring

content.summary: **Ghana signalled a return to normal debt servicing** by paying GHS 9.7 billion (~$708 million) of domestic bond coupons due in August:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}. This fifth post-exchange payment under Ghana’s Domestic Debt Exchange Programme (DDEP) brings **total interest serviced to GHS 19.4 billion in 2023-25**, reinforcing government commitment to honor restructured local debt. The **coupon settlement, made on 19 August**, was widely viewed by investors as a positive indicator of **fiscal discipline and improved liquidity** after Ghana’s 2023 domestic debt restructuring:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}. Market analysts noted that the timely payment and gradual resumption of longer-term bond issuance are **enhancing investor confidence** in Ghana’s economic recovery. Authorities are also **building cash buffers** to support future domestic debt repayments, as Ghana transitions back to regular capital market borrowing later this year. The successful servicing of local debt obligations complements Ghana’s external debt efforts and **may support credit rating stabilization** going forward.
next_milestones: Reopening of medium-term domestic bond auctions in Q4 2025
Conclusion of commercial external debt talks

items.headline: Ghana up to date on Eurobond payments after external debt deal, outlook improves

content.summary: The Ghanaian government announced it has **fully caught up on external bond service** following its recent debt restructuring. On 3 July, Ghana paid a **$349.5 million Eurobond coupon** – the second such payment in 2025 – bringing **total Eurobond debt service to ~$1.17 billion since the restructuring**:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}. After the October 2024 external debt exchange (which imposed a ~30% NPV reduction on creditors), Ghana has now met all **scheduled Eurobond obligations for 2025**:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}. The timely payments, alongside an initial $475 million disbursement last year, underscore Ghana’s renewed access to international capital and commitment to **treat external creditors equitably**. Officials noted this should **bolster Ghana’s credit outlook**, demonstrating disciplined post-default performance. Ghana faces a heavier external debt service of $1.41 billion in 2026:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}, but the government’s consistent payments under the IMF-supported program are expected to **support future rating upgrades** and sustain investor confidence. Focus now turns to finalising remaining commercial debt agreements to cement Ghana’s comprehensive debt resolution.
next_milestones: Negotiate outstanding commercial creditor terms by end-2025
Possible sovereign credit rating review in early 2026

items.headline: Zambia’s IMF program review clears $184 million disbursement as debt talks advance

content.summary: The **IMF Executive Board completed Zambia’s fifth ECF program review**, enabling an immediate disbursement of **SDR 139.9 million (≈$184 million)**:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}. The Board’s 25 July decision acknowledged Zambia’s **“broadly satisfactory” program performance**, with all end-2024 fiscal targets met. Zambia’s economy is rebounding (projected 5.8% GDP growth in 2025) and inflation is easing:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}, aided by the July adoption of a revised 2025 budget in line with consolidation commitments. Crucially, the IMF noted that Zambia’s **debt is now assessed as sustainable**, after last year’s landmark $6.3 billion official creditor deal, although the country remains at high risk of debt distress:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}. The government has **reached in-principle agreements** with most commercial bondholders and is finalising bilateral accords with remaining creditors:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}. Zambia’s cabinet is also seeking to **extend the IMF program by 12 months** beyond its October 2025 expiry to solidify reform gains:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}. The next milestone will be concluding those residual debt restructurings – including talks with smaller lenders like Afreximbank – before the sixth IMF review later this year.
next_milestones: Finalize private creditor restructuring terms (2025)
IMF 6th review and program extension decision (Q4 2025)

items.headline: IMF approves $262 million for Ethiopia amid debt talks stalemate with bondholders

content.summary: The IMF’s Executive Board **unanimously cleared Ethiopia’s third ECF program review**, unlocking **$262.3 million in financing** for the country:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}. The 2 July decision follows a **staff-level agreement on 30 May** and commends Ethiopia’s “strong results” in the first year of reforms under its 38-month Fund program. The Board’s approval came as Addis Ababa and its Official Creditor Committee – co-led by France and China – **finalised a Memorandum of Understanding** to restructure $8.4 billion of debt under the G20 Common Framework:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}. The draft deal, announced in March, targets $2.5 billion in debt-service relief through 2028, helping restore sustainability. However, **tensions persist with private creditors**: Ethiopia’s bondholders, who are owed $1 billion on a 2024 Eurobond, have **refused any haircut and threatened legal action**, claiming Ethiopia’s woes are liquidity-based:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}. The IMF defended its debt sustainability analysis, noting **Ethiopia must cut debt service by $3.5 billion** to achieve moderate risk levels:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}. With the official creditors’ terms set and Fund support on track, the spotlight shifts to **securing bondholder participation** and completing Ethiopia’s long-delayed restructuring in the coming months.
next_milestones: Ethiopia–China bilateral debt agreement signing (H2 2025)
Eurobond restructuring proposal and negotiations (2025)

items.headline: Chad secures new $625 million IMF program to anchor low debt and high growth

content.summary: **Chad obtained a fresh 48-month IMF Extended Credit Facility (ECF) arrangement of $625 million** to support its post-restructuring economic plan:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}. Approved on 25 July, the program immediately disburses $38.5 million and aims to **ensure fiscal sustainability, spur development spending, and boost governance**. The ECF will help Chad implement its ambitious **National Development Plan 2025–2030**, which envisions $30 billion of public-private investments in infrastructure and energy:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}. Notably, authorities target **average GDP growth of 8%** through 2030 and will cap public debt at **around 32% of GDP** during that period:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}. This comes after Chad’s recent oil-for-cash debt restructuring yielded limited relief due to prior full payments to Glencore. Under the new program, Chad’s junta-led government must pursue prudent budgets and structural reforms amid external pressures (oil price swings, Sudan refugee influx):contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}. The plan’s launch in Abu Dhabi this September will test donor support. With IMF backing and **debt now at a moderate level**, Chad is poised to maintain one of Africa’s lowest debt ratios, provided it adheres to fiscal targets and continues seeking concessional financing. The next review in early 2026 will assess progress in keeping deficits low and catalyzing promised development funds.
next_milestones: National Development Plan investment forum in Sep 2025
ECF first review (Q1 2026) evaluating fiscal targets

items.headline: IMF disburses $2 billion to Argentina as new program shows strong start

content.summary: The IMF Board **completed the first review** of Argentina’s new 48-month, $20 billion Extended Fund Facility (EFF), **approving a ~$2 billion disbursement** on 31 July:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}. The Fund noted Argentina’s **“strong policy implementation”** so far, citing tighter fiscal and monetary stances that have eased inflation and allowed a **smooth transition to a more flexible exchange rate**:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}. While Argentina narrowly missed a June net reserve accumulation target, corrective measures are underway and all other performance criteria were met. The IMF praised authorities’ commitments to **zero primary deficit** and to rebuilding foreign reserves:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}. Notably, Argentina has **re-accessed international capital markets** sooner than expected, with a successful $1 billion local-currency bond issuance that underscored returning investor confidence:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}. The EFF – approved in April to replace the country’s troubled 2018 program – has now disbursed $14 billion in total. With October 2025 elections on the horizon, the next review will focus on **cementing fiscal discipline** and sustaining disinflation. The IMF warned that consistent policy execution is critical to further restore market access and **avoid any new debt setbacks**.
next_milestones: Second EFF review (Q4 2025) – focus on reserve build-up
Continued market issuance to extend debt profile

items.headline: Kenya’s credit rating upgraded on reduced liquidity pressures and solid growth

content.summary: **S&P Global Ratings upgraded Kenya’s long-term sovereign rating to ‘B’ from ‘B-’** on 22 August, citing **easing external liquidity risks and resilient growth**:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}. The first notch upgrade for Kenya since 2018 reflects improvements in the country’s foreign exchange reserve position, boosted by robust export receipts (particularly tea and horticulture) and record diaspora remittances:contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37}. These inflows have shored up Kenya’s import cover and helped moderate pressure from its current account deficit. S&P expects Kenya’s **GDP to expand ~5.6% in 2025**, outpacing earlier forecasts despite headwinds from higher U.S. tariffs:contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}. This growth, alongside recent tax hikes and fuel subsidy reforms, is seen **offsetting the burden of elevated interest costs** on public debt. The outlook remains stable, with S&P projecting that **debt-to-GDP will gradually decline** from ~67% as fiscal consolidation progresses. President William Ruto welcomed the upgrade as validation of Kenya’s economic reforms, including spending cuts that trimmed the budget deficit to 5.8% of GDP. The **rating lift may lower Kenya’s borrowing costs** as it plans to refinance a $2 billion Eurobond in 2025. S&P warned, however, that any faltering in fiscal discipline or growth could stall further rating gains.
next_milestones: Possible Eurobond issuance or refinancing in 2025
Implementation of FY2025 budget to hit 4.3% deficit target

items.headline: India earns first S&P rating upgrade in 18 years as growth and policies impress

content.summary: **S&P Global Ratings upgraded India’s sovereign credit rating from ‘BBB-’ to ‘BBB’** (stable outlook) on 14 August, **the country’s first S&P upgrade since 2007**:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}. S&P highlighted **India’s buoyant economic growth (8.8% average in 2022–24)**, improved monetary policy credibility, and steady fiscal consolidation as key drivers:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}:contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}. The agency expects India to sustain ~6.8% annual GDP growth through 2027 – the fastest in Asia-Pacific – which should gradually ease the government’s debt burden (currently ~83% of GDP) despite still-large deficits:contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}:contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}. S&P’s upgrade comes after it raised India’s outlook to positive last year and follows wide-ranging reforms: inflation targeting by the RBI, a national goods and services tax, and moderation of subsidy spending. The Finance Ministry welcomed the news as validation of its goal to make India a developed economy by 2047:contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}. Markets reacted positively: the rupee ticked up to ₹87.6/$ and 10-year bond yields fell 7 bps to 6.38% on the announcement:contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}. S&P cautioned that risks remain – a reversal on deficit reduction or a **structural growth slowdown** could stall progress:contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}. The government hopes Moody’s and Fitch will “take note” and follow suit, which would lift India fully out of the lowest investment-grade tier:contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}:contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48}.
next_milestones: Moody’s and Fitch rating reviews (2025–2026)
Further fiscal consolidation targeting <6% combined deficit

items.headline: Fitch affirms India at ‘BBB-’ but flags high debt and looming US tariffs

content.summary: In contrast to S&P’s recent upgrade, **Fitch Ratings reaffirmed India’s sovereign IDR at ‘BBB-’** (stable) on 25 August, **declining to raise the rating** over concerns about the country’s still-high debt and deficits:contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}:contentReference[oaicite:50]{index=50}. Fitch noted India’s **government debt stands near 81% of GDP**, far above the ‘BBB’ median (~60%), and projected it will edge up to **81.5% by FY2026** given only gradual fiscal improvement:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51}:contentReference[oaicite:52]{index=52}. The agency warned that if India’s nominal GDP growth slows below 10% (it’s currently ~11% in rupee terms), **debt reduction would become challenging**:contentReference[oaicite:53]{index=53}. Fitch’s decision comes **two days before a new 50% US tariff on Indian imports takes effect**, part of Washington’s response to India’s oil trade with Russia:contentReference[oaicite:54]{index=54}. The rating report cautioned these hefty tariffs pose a “moderate downside risk” to India’s growth and could dent investor sentiment, though Fitch expects India’s domestic-demand-driven economy to weather the impact:contentReference[oaicite:55]{index=55}:contentReference[oaicite:56]{index=56}. The firm maintained a stable outlook, balancing India’s robust 6.5% real growth forecast and improved external buffers against its weak public finances. Fitch indicated it might **consider an upgrade** if India decisively shrinks its fiscal deficit (8.9% of GDP combined), but for now it remains the lone major agency not to lift India from the lowest investment grade.
next_milestones: Monitor impact of 50% US tariffs (effective Aug 27, 2025)
FY2026 Union Budget (Feb 2026) – potential deficit reduction measures

items.headline: Moody’s restores Oman to investment grade on sustained debt ratio improvements

content.summary: **Moody’s upgraded Oman’s sovereign rating to Baa3 (investment grade)** from Ba1 on 10 July, reflecting the Gulf state’s markedly **strengthened debt metrics and fiscal resilience**:contentReference[oaicite:57]{index=57}. The agency expects Oman’s government debt-to-GDP and interest burdens to remain **“robust” at Baa3 levels even if oil prices moderate** to around $65/barrel:contentReference[oaicite:58]{index=58}. This positive outlook stems from Muscat’s sweeping fiscal reforms and windfall hydrocarbon revenues over the past two years, which have **halved Oman’s debt ratio** (from ~70% of GDP in 2020 to ~40% in 2024). The upgrade comes as Oman runs budget surpluses and has used surplus oil income to prepay loans and build buffers. Moody’s did revise Oman’s outlook down to stable from positive, warning that **heavy reliance on oil** still leaves the medium-term fiscal path vulnerable to any sustained drop in energy demand or prices:contentReference[oaicite:59]{index=59}. Nonetheless, the improved rating affords Oman cheaper external financing and validates its 2021–2025 Fiscal Balance Plan. Officials noted that **greater fiscal space** will allow Oman more time to implement structural economic diversification, reducing hydrocarbon dependence over time. Oman’s 5-year CDS spreads tightened to multi-year lows after the announcement, reflecting market confidence in its **deleveraging trajectory**.
next_milestones: Next Moody’s review in 2026 – assess diversification progress
Continued prepayment of high-cost debt through 2025

items.headline: Fitch downgrades China to ‘A’ citing rising debt and weaker local finances

content.summary: **Fitch Ratings downgraded China’s sovereign credit rating by one notch** to ‘A’ from ‘A+’ on 3 April, assigning a stable outlook:contentReference[oaicite:60]{index=60}. It was the first major agency downgrade of China since 1999 and reflects **concerns over the country’s mounting debt and fiscal strains** in the wake of heavy stimulus and a property downturn. Fitch cited expectations that Beijing will **increase central government debt to support provinces and troubled local financing vehicles**, whose off-balance-sheet borrowings have surged. China’s general government debt is now estimated above 60% of GDP (up sharply from ~52% in 2019), and **broad credit in the economy tops 280% of GDP**:contentReference[oaicite:61]{index=61}. Fitch forecasts China’s economic growth to slow to 4.4% in 2025 from 5.0% in 2024 amid weak consumer confidence and a shrinking housing sector:contentReference[oaicite:62]{index=62}:contentReference[oaicite:63]{index=63}. This weaker outlook limits China’s capacity to “grow out” of its debt. The Ministry of Finance criticized Fitch’s move as **ignoring China’s ample domestic funding and policy tools**, but markets took the cut in stride, with minimal impact on Chinese government bond yields. Fitch maintained a stable outlook, balancing debt concerns against China’s still-solid external finances (over $3 trillion in FX reserves) and moderate inflation. The downgrade underscores rising pressure on Beijing to **rein in local government liabilities** and stabilize the property sector to avoid further slippage in creditworthiness.
next_milestones: Expected announcement of local debt restructuring framework (2025)
Fitch review of China rating by late 2026

items.headline: Moody’s shifts Italy’s outlook to positive after fiscal gains, as S&P boosts rating

content.summary: **Moody’s Investors Service raised Italy’s credit outlook to “positive”** (from stable) on 23 May, citing a **“better-than-expected” fiscal outturn in 2024 and improved political stability** under PM Giorgia Meloni’s government:contentReference[oaicite:64]{index=64}:contentReference[oaicite:65]{index=65}. Moody’s affirmed Italy’s Baa3 rating (one notch above junk) but noted that **credible deficit reduction and robust growth** could lead to an upgrade. Italy’s deficit fell to 8.0% of GDP in 2024, beating targets, and the government projects it at 3.3% in 2025 – on track to dip below the EU’s 3% ceiling by 2026:contentReference[oaicite:66]{index=66}. A “stable” coalition and structural reforms (notably on pensions and tax administration) support the positive outlook:contentReference[oaicite:67]{index=67}. This move follows **S&P’s surprise upgrade of Italy to ‘BBB+’ (stable) in April** – its highest rating since 2012 – which came just after Rome trimmed its 2025 growth forecast amid US-EU trade uncertainty:contentReference[oaicite:68]{index=68}. Italy’s colossal public debt (~137% of GDP) remains a constraint, though it is edging down from pandemic highs and is now forecast at 136.6% this year:contentReference[oaicite:69]{index=69}. Moody’s highlighted Italy’s “robust” job market, healthy bank balance sheets and strong household finances as buffers supporting debt sustainability:contentReference[oaicite:70]{index=70}. Further rating upside will depend on Italy navigating slower growth (0.6% expected in 2025) while staying the course on fiscal consolidation and fully deploying EU NextGen funds to spur investment.
next_milestones: Italy Baa3 rating review (H2 2025) – potential upgrade if deficits drop
EU fiscal rules reinstatement in 2024 – adherence to 3% deficit

items.headline: South Sudan ordered to pay $657 million after UK court ruling on defaulted loans

content.summary: **South Sudan lost a high-profile legal case in London**, where the High Court ruled the country must pay **$657 million to Afreximbank** over defaulted oil-backed loans:contentReference[oaicite:71]{index=71}. The May judgment – related to a 2020 financing agreement – underscores how commercial creditors can bypass the G20 Common Framework when debts are under English law. South Sudan, which has faced civil conflict and chronic liquidity shortages, stopped servicing the high-interest Afreximbank loans in 2020. With accrued interest and penalties, the court’s award amounts to **nearly 15% of South Sudan’s GDP**. The verdict highlights a **growing trend of private lenders suing sovereigns**: South Sudan had sought relief via the Common Framework, but Afreximbank (not bound by it) pursued litigation to recover full value:contentReference[oaicite:72]{index=72}. Debt campaigners note this outcome effectively forces Juba to divert scarce funds from essential imports to creditor repayment. The case has broader implications – without UK legislation to **shield countries in restructuring from such lawsuits**, other nations (like **Zambia and Ghana**) risk similar actions by holdouts:contentReference[oaicite:73]{index=73}. South Sudan’s defeat may deter it from officially seeking Common Framework treatment, as its external loans (including to Afreximbank and oil traders) mostly carry English governing law. Going forward, South Sudan will need to **renegotiate a payment schedule** or face asset seizures, complicating its already fraught debt situation and demonstrating the clout of legal enforcement in sovereign debt.
next_milestones: Negotiations on judgment payment terms (2025)
Potential UK legislative debate on sovereign debt stays

items.headline: Global campaigners urge new debt workout mechanism as slow restructurings persist

content.summary: Civil society organizations renewed calls for an **independent sovereign debt resolution mechanism** amid evidence that current processes are failing debtor nations. In an 11 August commentary, the Bretton Woods Project highlighted Sri Lanka’s plight – **17 IMF programs since 1965** yet still in crisis – as emblematic of the need for systemic reform. Campaigners argue that the **G20 Common Framework has delivered only piecemeal relief**, with protracted negotiations (over two years for Zambia, nearly three for Ethiopia) and **key private creditors refusing to participate**:contentReference[oaicite:74]{index=74}. For instance, **Ethiopia’s bondholders rejected a deal and threatened UK court action** to pressure a better outcome, while Ghana and Zambia have seen **Western commercial lenders hold out** well after official creditors agreed haircuts:contentReference[oaicite:75]{index=75}:contentReference[oaicite:76]{index=76}. The groups propose a UN-led debt workout mechanism to impose **standstills (automatic payment halts)** and **cram-down restructurings** that bind all creditors, preventing vulture funds from free-riding. They also urge legislation (particularly in the UK and US) to stop creditor lawsuits during negotiations:contentReference[oaicite:77]{index=77}:contentReference[oaicite:78]{index=78}. The commentary gained traction as development NGOs and some UN officials back the idea of a global sovereign bankruptcy process. While no concrete new mechanism has emerged yet, the persistent delays – Chad’s private creditors were paid in full during stalled talks, and **South Sudan was sued for $657m**:contentReference[oaicite:79]{index=79} – add momentum to calls for bold reform at upcoming international forums (such as the UN General Assembly in September). Observers note that **without a fairer arbitration system**, debt crises will likely continue to be resolved slowly and inequitably.
next_milestones: UN General Assembly discussion on debt (Sept 2025)
Potential tabling of UK Debt Reform Bill in Parliament (Q4 2025)

items.headline: US national debt tops $37.2 trillion, reigniting debates on fiscal discipline

content.summary: The **gross US federal debt hit a record $37.2 trillion on 18 August**, according to the Treasury Department:contentReference[oaicite:80]{index=80}. The milestone comes just two months after Washington suspended the debt ceiling, and it has intensified the partisan dispute over government spending and deficits. The debt load – equal to roughly 122% of US GDP – is rising faster amid higher interest rates; the Congressional Budget Office projects net interest costs will double over the next decade. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent indicated the administration is exploring **applying part of hefty tariff revenues ($29 billion in July alone) to debt reduction**:contentReference[oaicite:81]{index=81}:contentReference[oaicite:82]{index=82}, as import duties collected under President Trump’s trade policies reach new highs. However, fiscal analysts note that tariffs cover only a fraction of the $2 trillion annual deficit. **Republican lawmakers renewed calls for spending cuts**, while Democrats argue revenue measures are needed to stabilize the debt trajectory. The US has now **exceeded pre-pandemic debt ratios by over 20 percentage points**, raising concerns from rating agencies. Fitch’s 2023 downgrade of the US cited governance and debt burden worries, and Moody’s recently warned that without a credible medium-term fiscal plan, the US could risk losing its last AAA rating. The next flashpoint will be budget negotiations ahead of the new fiscal year on 1 October, where hawks are pushing for caps to discretionary outlays to **signal a return to discipline**.
next_milestones: FY2026 budget deal deadline (30 Sept 2025)
2026 presidential campaign fiscal policy platforms

items.headline: Fitch nudges Argentina’s rating up as program progress eases default risk

content.summary: Fitch Ratings **upgraded Argentina’s long-term foreign currency rating to ‘CCC+’ from ‘CCC’** on 4 June:contentReference[oaicite:83]{index=83}, citing reduced immediate default risk after the new IMF program and exchange rate reforms took hold. The one-notch uplift comes as Argentina has stabilized its finances in recent months – inflation, while still high, has decelerated from triple digits, and international reserves have stopped falling thanks to a more market-driven peso. Fitch noted that Argentina’s near-term external debt payments are largely covered by the IMF’s disbursements and a 2024 bond buyback operation, which **alleviates short-term liquidity pressure**. The outlook remains constrained by Argentina’s still-fragile reserve buffer and political uncertainty ahead of the October 2025 general election. **Further rating improvement is contingent on continued adherence to the IMF fiscal targets** (zero primary deficit this year) and successful liability management to push out maturities. Nonetheless, the upgrade reflects a modestly more optimistic view that Argentina can avoid another hard default in the next 12–18 months, provided the policy path stays on course. Fitch also pointed to the **recent $1 billion local-currency bond issuance** as evidence of returning investor confidence. Argentina’s rating is still deeply speculative, but this marks the first step upward since its 2020 default, aligning Fitch with S&P (CCC+) in rating Argentina’s creditworthiness.
next_milestones: October 2025 election outcomes and economic policies
Further liability management operations on USD bonds (2025–2026)

items.headline: Nigeria’s credit ratings upgraded as reforms bolster external position

content.summary: **International rating agencies have raised Nigeria’s credit ratings** following a wave of market-friendly reforms by the new government. Fitch Ratings **upgraded Nigeria’s IDR to ‘B’ from ‘B-’** on 11 April (with stable outlook), and Moody’s **lifted Nigeria’s rating to ‘B3’ from ‘Caa1’** on 30 May:contentReference[oaicite:84]{index=84}. Both moves move Nigeria out of highly speculative territory, reflecting **increased confidence in its economic management**. President Bola Tinubu’s administration swiftly ended a costly fuel subsidy and unified exchange rates in mid-2025, steps which have improved Nigeria’s fiscal and external metrics. Moody’s cited “significant improvements in external and fiscal positions” – foreign reserves got a boost from the FX reform and growth picked up to a decade-high ~4%:contentReference[oaicite:85]{index=85}:contentReference[oaicite:86]{index=86}. Fitch similarly noted that Nigeria’s governance and willingness to enact difficult reforms have **reduced near-term default risk**, and forecast the public debt ratio to remain moderate (~35% of GDP). As a result of the upgrades, Nigeria’s Eurobond yields have fallen to 3-year lows and **investor sentiment has turned neutral from underweight**:contentReference[oaicite:87]{index=87}. However, both agencies kept outlooks stable, balancing the positive reform momentum against Nigeria’s still-daunting challenges – double-digit inflation, large debt service costs (over 90% of federal revenue), and oil production uncertainties. Further rating gains may require sustained non-oil revenue growth and institutional strengthening, but for now **Nigeria’s credit trajectory is firmly upward**.
next_milestones: S&P rating review of Nigeria (expected late 2025)
2026 budget – test of subsidy removal savings

items.headline: Guatemala attains S&P upgrade to ‘BB+’ as prudent policies sustain low debt

content.summary: **Standard & Poor’s upgraded Guatemala’s sovereign credit rating to ‘BB+’ from ‘BB’** (outlook stable) on 23 May, reflecting the Central American nation’s consistent macroeconomic stability and low debt burden. S&P expects Guatemala’s economy to grow ~3.0% annually over 2025–26, a slight easing from the 3.6% average of 2023–24 as post-pandemic momentum moderates:contentReference[oaicite:88]{index=88}:contentReference[oaicite:89]{index=89}. Even so, prudent fiscal management – including conservative budgets and improved tax collection – has kept Guatemala’s **public debt around 25% of GDP**, one of the lowest in emerging markets:contentReference[oaicite:90]{index=90}. S&P noted that Guatemala navigated recent shocks (commodity price swings and regional spillovers) without significant deterioration in its external accounts or banking system. The upgrade puts Guatemala just one notch below investment grade and may reduce sovereign borrowing costs. President Alejandro Giammattei welcomed the news as validation of Guatemala’s investor-friendly policies and a stable political climate. The outlook is stable, with S&P saying further upgrades would require faster medium-term growth (contingent on infrastructure investment and human capital gains) or sustained tax reforms to expand the revenue base. Fitch and Moody’s already have Guatemala at BB and Ba1, respectively, both with positive outlooks following this S&P action. Guatemala’s Finance Ministry signaled it will continue to prioritize **attracting foreign investment and maintaining low deficits** to eventually reach the coveted ‘BBB’ category.

items.headline: Bolivia’s bonds surge 30% on reform hopes, but default fears linger as reserves dwindle

content.summary: Bolivia’s dollar bonds have rallied to their **highest levels in over two years**, gaining 30% in 2025 to date:contentReference[oaicite:91]{index=91}, as investors bet that a pro-market opposition victory in the 17 August presidential election could unlock an IMF lifeline. The prospect of a new administration reversing unorthodox policies – such as the fixed exchange rate and monetized deficits – has fueled hopes Bolivia can avert a debt crisis. However, **underlying indicators remain alarming**: inflation is at a 40-year high, and central bank reserves plunged to just **$165 million in April** (barely 2 months of imports):contentReference[oaicite:92]{index=92}:contentReference[oaicite:93]{index=93}. The government faces over $300 million in annual external debt service in 2026–27, up sharply from $54 million this year:contentReference[oaicite:94]{index=94}. Analysts warn that without swift reforms or external support, Bolivia may be forced to **choose between debt repayment and critical imports** in coming years:contentReference[oaicite:95]{index=95}:contentReference[oaicite:96]{index=96}. Citi recently upgraded Bolivia’s bonds to neutral, noting they trade around 75 cents on the dollar – above distressed levels – amid optimism a new government will **seek an IMF program** to stabilize finances:contentReference[oaicite:97]{index=97}:contentReference[oaicite:98]{index=98}. Such an IMF deal could ease liquidity via dollar loans and possibly forestall a painful debt restructuring. In the meantime, Bolivia’s parallel market exchange rate is 80% weaker than the official peg, underscoring severe FX shortages:contentReference[oaicite:99]{index=99}. The election outcome and policy responses in its aftermath will determine whether Bolivia’s bond rally has overshot fundamentals or correctly anticipates **a turnaround that averts default**.
